bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to George A. Kellogg, November 17, 1941

div1.p: Lambert thanks Kellogg for the copy of the Cornwell painting. He gives his opinion of Ames, stating that he has not received the credit he deserved. He hopes that a copy of the painting was sent to his wife, Jessie Ames.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to George A. Kellogg, November 17, 1941
div1.opener:
C O P Y
Chicago, November 17, 1941.
Mr. George A. Kellogg
Jersey City, N. J.
Dear Mr. Kellogg
div1.p:
Thank you very much for the copy of Mr. Cornwell's
picture. Yes, I knew and had dealings at one time or another with
every one in the picture from, Gen. Wood on down.

I nursed every one of the experimental cases be-
sides some forty natural cases. Gen. Kean was one of them.

With regards to the picture it is fine but I wish
I had known that it was going to be painted and I would have sent
a photograph of Dr. Ames so his face could have been recognized. I
have a photograph taken only two months after the experiment was
completed. To me Dr. Ames was the hero. I nursed over sixty cases
of yellow fever for Dr. Ames. He lost only one. The man had been a
heavy drinker. Sir, I hope you will forgive the nerve of an old
man, but if Mrs. Ames hasn't received a copy will you please give
her one also. I know she will appreciate it.

closer.signed:
Gust. E. Lambert
4718 Wood lawn Avenue
Chicago, Illinois
